headline: Caribbean Green Seasoning
description: Season your meat, fish, stews and rice with this Caribbean green seasoning cooking base‚Äìa blend of fresh green herbs and aromatics. It'll take your cooking to the next level.
name: Caribbean Green Seasoning
recipeIngredient: 6 Trinidadian pimento peppers or 1 red or green Cubanelle pepper
4 Guyanese wiri wiri peppers (or 1 Scotch bonnet or 2 to 3 habaneros)

recipeInstructions.text: Prep the vegetables and herbs: Rinse the peppers, green onions and green herbs. Remove the stems from any of the hot peppers.¬† If using Cubanelle peppers, remove stems and seeds. Roughly chop the green onions. Remove the leaves from the hard woody parts of the thyme sprigs. You can leave the tender parts of the stem with leaves intact.

Add to the food processor and pulse: It‚Äôs best to do this in two parts. Add half of the ingredients to the food processor and pulse on high for a few seconds. Open the lid, then scrape the sides with a small spatula or spoon. Put the lid back on and pulse until the seasoning resembles a paste or thick marinade. Repeat with the remaining half of the ingredients.

Store: Store your seasoning in a glass jar with a tight lid. I like using a mason jar. Avoid using any plastic containers to store this in the fridge, as plastic can‚Äôt contain the seasoning‚Äôs strong aroma.¬† To freeze, fill the crevices of an ice cube tray with spoonfuls of seasoning. Cover with a lid. If you do not have a matching lid for your tray then double wrap the top with plastic wrap to avoid freezer burn. Once frozen, pop each out and place in a freezer bag. The seasoning will keep in the fridge for up to 2 weeks and up to 6 months in the freezer. Love the recipe? Leave us stars and a comment below!

review.reviewBody:
Articles like this are very helpful in demystifying Caribbean cooking. Another recipe on the Web lists ingredients as ‚Äúcilantro, parsley, celery, green onions, garlic, onion, ginger, thyme, Scotch Bonnet pepper.‚Äù

I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôre letting people know there are broad parameters and they are not going to go broke trying different versions. It's a great marinade.

Blend it. Use it. Very easy. I have a blender with a ‚Äúsalsa‚Äù mode that is so helpful‚Ä¶the rhythm (if you will) shifts so that heavier items have a chance to settle and get caught by the blades. The blades don‚Äôt just spin wildly. 

I had very good luck making green seasoning last week and cooking up a pot of Trinidadian curry chicken. Legs and thighs, skin removed, marinade in green seasoning, then curry powder (from scratch) made into a slurry for simmering. And I just made another batch of seasoning today.

On another note. I may try tomato for sofrito one day, but my standard approach is exclusively red bell peppers for color with habaneros added for heat.

Thanks again!

Greetings in all languages ü§ó

I 'went' to several of the cultural places just reading through the ingredients and recipes .
I think the 'taste' I've acquired , has my mouth watering for testing these recipes in my kitchen .
How well you portrayed the varied ingredient additions (and amounts) for each recipe .
Thank you for your description and easy to understand article üçΩÔ∏è
